html:
What the discovery of the double-helix DNA structure can teach us about presenting data.

Have you heard of the DNA double-helix? In this day and age, it’s almost a dumb question. Most people today can name or describe the double-helix, even if you’ve never been to college. And, it’s so because of one reason: the scientists who reported it told a great story.

The same goes for you. After you’ve gathered all of the data and the evidence, how will you make a compelling story? By dumping all of it into a dizzying array of charts? Convincing, no?

Before getting to that, let’s look at how the DNA double-helix model came about. It will help us understand what a good story can do.

The double helix discovery: competition

The scientists who reported the double helix were Watson and Crick. However, like most scientific discoveries, they weren’t alone on the path to discovery. Others uncovered and reported the structure at the same time. Even in the same journal.

In the book, Writing Science, Joshua Schimel describes one such paper. This paper (by Franklin and Gosling) showed the first-ever image of the structure. But, to scientists outside of the specialty, it didn’t mean…
